study_goal: The researchers aimed to compare the effects of whey protein supplementation alone versus whey protein plus creatine on body composition and performance in resistance-trained women.
results_summary: Both groups showed similar increases in lean mass and performance measures over 8 weeks, with no significant differences between whey protein alone and whey protein plus creatine supplementation.
population_specificity: Resistance-trained women (n=17, aged 21 ± 3 years, >6 months of training).
effective_dosage: 24 g whey protein (PRO group) or 24 g whey protein plus 5 g creatine monohydrate (PRO + CRE group) post-exercise.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to assess the feasibility, safety, and efficacy of co-supplementation with creatine and whey protein combined with resistance training in older individuals with frailty.
results_summary: Both whey protein with creatine (WHEY+CR) and whey protein alone (WHEY) similarly improved muscle function, with no significant differences between groups. Body composition and blood parameters remained unchanged, and no severe adverse effects were observed.
population_specificity: Older individuals with frailty.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether a proprietary blend of ancient peat and apple extract enhances athletic performance when used during 12 weeks of supervised, periodized resistance training.
results_summary: The supplement group (TRT) showed significant improvements in squat and deadlift 1RM, vertical jump peak power, and peak velocity compared to the placebo group (PLA). Wingate peak power and relative power also tended to favor TRT, though results were less definitive.
population_specificity: 25 healthy, resistance-trained male subjects.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether NSAID treatment influences muscle loss during immobilization and subsequent rehabilitation resistance training in elderly individuals.
results_summary: Muscle mass and strength decreased after 2 weeks of immobilization but were restored after 2 weeks of retraining with whey protein supplementation. After 6 weeks of retraining, muscle mass and strength exceeded baseline levels, with no significant effect from NSAID treatment.
population_specificity: Elderly men aged 60-80 years.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to investigate the effects of elastic band resistance training and nutritional supplementation on muscle growth, degradation factors, physical performance, and muscle quality in institutionalized elderly women.
results_summary: Resistance training (RT) and RT plus nutritional supplementation (RTS) significantly improved muscle quality and physical performance (e.g., chair stand test) after 6 months. The improvements appeared mediated by increased follistatin and reduced activin A-to-follistatin ratio, not by IGF-1 or myostatin pathways.
population_specificity: Institutionalized elderly women (aged 65.0–92.2 years, mean 83.6).
effective_dosage: Not specified (elastic band resistance training frequency/intensity not detailed).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to investigate the effects of Fortetropin on skeletal muscle growth, strength, and anabolic/catabolic signaling in resistance-trained individuals using both human and rodent models.
results_summary: Fortetropin supplementation increased lean body mass and muscle thickness in resistance-trained humans, while reducing markers of protein breakdown and enhancing mTOR signaling in rodents. Strength gains were similar across all human groups.
population_specificity: Resistance-trained college-aged males (human study); male Wistar rats (rodent study).
effective_dosage: 6.6 g or 19.8 g Fortetropin daily (human study); 0.26 g Fortetropin for 8 days (rodent study).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine the effectiveness of BCAA supplementation combined with heavy resistance training and a hypocaloric diet on body composition and muscle fitness in trained individuals.
results_summary: The BCAA group lost fat mass while maintaining lean mass and showed greater strength gains in 1RM squat and bench press compared to the CHO group, which lost lean mass and body mass and decreased in bench press strength. The CHO group showed an increase in muscular endurance.
population_specificity: Seventeen resistance-trained males aged 21-28 years.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether ashwagandha root extract supplementation enhances muscle mass and strength in healthy young men undergoing resistance training.
results_summary: The study found that ashwagandha supplementation significantly increased muscle strength (bench press and leg extension), muscle size (arms and chest), testosterone levels, and muscle recovery while reducing body fat percentage compared to placebo.
population_specificity: Healthy young men (18-50 years old) with little resistance training experience.
effective_dosage: 300 mg of ashwagandha root extract twice daily.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to compare the effects of high-intensity resistance training (HIT) with and without protein supplementation (HIT&P) and high-volume/high-intensity training (HVHIT) on cardiometabolic risk factors in untrained males.
results_summary: All exercise groups (HIT, HIT&P, HVHIT) significantly improved the metabolic syndrome Z-Score (MetS-Z-Score) compared to the control group, with no significant differences between the exercise protocols. The control group showed a significant deterioration in MetS-Z-Score.
population_specificity: Untrained males aged 30-50 years.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to systematically review the role of vitamin D in neuromuscular remodelling following exercise conditioning or injury, focusing on its effects on muscle strength, recovery, and inflammation.
results_summary: The study found that vitamin D supplementation showed no significant effect on muscle strength adaptation after resistance training or muscle damage in humans, though it elevated inflammatory markers. Animal models suggested improved recovery with vitamin D, but human results were inconclusive and likely influenced by baseline vitamin D levels and supplementation strategy.
population_specificity: Human and animal models (specific populations not detailed in the abstract).

study_goal: To investigate whether combining nutritional supplementation with resistance training improves skeletal muscle mass and activities of daily living in elderly patients with disabilities during convalescent rehabilitation.
results_summary: The study found that resistance training combined with nutritional supplementation significantly improved calf circumference, arm circumference, Barthel Index scores, and serum albumin levels compared to resistance training alone. These results suggest that nutritional intervention enhances the benefits of resistance training for muscle mass and daily functioning in elderly rehabilitation patients.
population_specificity: Elderly inpatients with decreased skeletal muscle mass in a convalescent rehabilitation unit.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether whey protein-containing supplements, alone or as part of a multi-ingredient, improve fat-free mass, lean body mass, and strength in resistance-trained individuals compared to iso-energetic carbohydrate or non-whey protein supplements.
results_summary: Whey protein supplementation, alone or in multi-ingredient form, was associated with small extra gains in fat-free mass or lean body mass and improved upper and lower body strength, with multi-ingredient formulations showing more pronounced effects in upper body strength.
population_specificity: Resistance-trained adults aged 18 years and over.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine the effects of daily ginsenoside Rb1 supplementation on circulating glucose and insulin levels in men during a 5-day recovery period after acute resistance exercise.
results_summary: The study found no significant effect of Rb1 on glucose or insulin levels during recovery. A persistent elevation in sympathetic nervous activity (indicated by increased HRV-LF/HF power) was observed during Rb1 supplementation.
population_specificity: Twelve gymnasts (20.5 ± 0.3 years of age)

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the potential benefits of progressive resistance training, combined with nutritional strategies, in optimizing body composition and muscle function to reduce falls and fracture risk in older adults with sarcopenic and dynapenic obesity.
results_summary: The study suggests that resistance training, alongside protein and vitamin D supplementation, may improve body composition and muscle function, thereby reducing falls and fracture risk in obese older adults with sarcopenia or dynapenia. However, weight loss interventions alone may negatively impact muscle and bone health.
population_specificity: Older adults with sarcopenic obesity and dynapenic obesity.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to investigate the effects of creatine supplementation combined with resistance training on homocysteine and lipid profiles in young males.
results_summary: Creatine supplementation with resistance training significantly reduced homocysteine levels compared to baseline, while placebo with resistance training showed no significant change. No significant differences were observed among groups in homocysteine levels, suggesting creatine may offer cardiovascular protection alongside strength gains.
population_specificity: 60 male university students (22.34 ± 2.19 years, 15.48 ± 4.57% body fat).
effective_dosage: 25 g/day for the first 5 days, followed by 5 g/day thereafter.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine if combining protein supplementation with resistance training was more effective than standard care in counteracting muscle loss in acutely ill elderly patients.
results_summary: The study found no significant effect of the intervention on lean mass. The Control Group showed a significant increase in the de Morton Mobility Index, but no other differences were observed. Resistance training compliance was noted as challenging.
population_specificity: Acutely admitted elderly patients (>65 years)
effective_dosage: 1.7 g protein/kg/day during admission, plus a daily 18.8 g protein supplement post-discharge; resistance training 3 times per week

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether a proprietary blend of ancient peat and apple extracts could enhance body composition when consumed during 12 weeks of resistance training.
results_summary: The study found that the supplement increased ultrasound-determined cross-sectional area and muscle thickness compared to placebo, without affecting fat mass or blood chemistry. Blood markers like creatinine, triglycerides, and very-low-density lipoprotein showed changes but remained within clinical ranges.
population_specificity: 25 healthy, resistance-trained males (age 27.7 ± 4.8 years).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine the optimal daily protein intake for obese older adults during weight loss to promote muscle mass accretion when combined with resistance training.
results_summary: The study found that protein intake of at least 1.2 g/kg body weight or 1.9 g/kg fat-free mass significantly increased muscle mass accretion during weight loss, with higher intake correlating with greater muscle mass gains. Resistance training combined with adequate protein intake led to 70-72% of subjects achieving muscle mass accretion compared to 28-33% with lower protein intake.
population_specificity: Obese older adults (60 participants, aged unspecified)
effective_dosage: 20 g protein supplement 10 times weekly (in addition to dietary protein)

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether six months of progressive resistance training (with or without protein/vitamin supplementation or cognitive training) reduces chromosomal damage in institutionalized elderly individuals.
results_summary: All intervention groups showed a tendency toward reduced chromosomal damage (-15% in cells with micronuclei, -20% in total micronuclei), though the changes were not statistically significant. Vitamin B12 and folate supplementation correlated with reduced chromosomal damage in the supplemented group.
population_specificity: Institutionalized Austrian women and men aged 65-98 years.
effective_dosage: Not specified (progressive resistance training, protein/vitamin supplementation, or cognitive training).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to summarize recent findings on the adjuvant use of creatine supplementation with resistance training to manage age-related deficits in skeletal muscle, bone, and brain metabolism in older individuals.
results_summary: Creatine supplementation combined with resistance training improves lean mass and muscle function in older populations, with benefits applicable regardless of sex, fitness, or health status. Effects on bone remodeling are inconsistent, and cognitive benefits are suggested but require further study in older adults.
population_specificity: Older individuals, with limited data on very old (>90 years) and severely frail individuals.
study_duration: Suggested need for longer durations (>52 weeks)

study_goal: The researchers aimed to analyze the beneficial effects of resistance training in the prevention and treatment of non-alcoholic fatty liver disease (NAFLD).
results_summary: Resistance training was found to reduce lipogenic gene expression, fat accumulation, and insulin resistance while improving cardiorespiratory fitness, with benefits persisting even after exercise cessation.
population_specificity: Adults with or at risk of NAFLD.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine the effect of 12 months of creatine supplementation combined with resistance training on bone properties in postmenopausal women.
results_summary: Creatine supplementation attenuated femoral neck bone mineral density loss and increased femoral shaft subperiosteal width compared to placebo, while also improving relative bench press strength. No differences were observed in other outcome measures, and no adverse effects on liver enzymes or creatinine clearance were noted.
population_specificity: Postmenopausal women (mean age 57 years).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether resistance training (RT) combined with amino acid supplementation could mitigate the metabolically unfavorable effects of 28 days of bed rest (BR) in middle-aged men.
results_summary: Resistance training helped maintain a healthier metabolic profile during bed rest, including preserving muscle density, though it did not completely prevent unfavorable metabolic changes. Both groups showed increased IGF-1 levels, but no changes in TNFα were observed.
population_specificity: Male individuals aged 30-55 years
study_duration: 28 days of bed rest with intervention

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether protein supplementation enhances the effects of resistance training on muscle mass and strength in older adults.
results_summary: Protein supplementation combined with resistance training was associated with gains in fat-free mass but did not significantly increase muscle mass or strength. The study noted variability in supplementation protocols and low general quality among included studies.
population_specificity: Older adults aged 60-79 years.
effective_dosage: Varied—some studies used body mass-related quantities, others provided fixed daily amounts.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the role of progressive resistance training as an intervention for sarcopenia in older adults.
results_summary: The study found that progressive resistance training is the most well-established intervention for sarcopenia, improving muscle mass and function in older people. The efficacy of dietary supplementation and other potential treatments like angiotensin-converting enzyme inhibitors remains less clear.
population_specificity: Older adults with or at risk of sarcopenia.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether resistance training could mitigate the cytotoxic effects of creatine supplementation, specifically its impact on urinary formaldehyde excretion and serum enzyme levels.
results_summary: Resistance training partially reduced the increase in urinary formaldehyde excretion caused by creatine supplementation by 17.7%, though no significant changes were observed in serum enzyme levels.
population_specificity: Young male wrestlers

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether resistance training combined with protein supplementation increases resting metabolic rate (RMR) and if RMR changes could be estimated using DXA metabolic mapping.
results_summary: Resistance training over 9 months increased RMR by ~5% on average, with no significant differences between whey, soy, or carbohydrate supplementation groups. Variability in RMR changes was partially explained by baseline fat-free mass and thyroid hormone levels.
population_specificity: Healthy adults

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether protein supplementation enhances muscle mass, strength, and physical performance in response to resistance training.
results_summary: Protein supplementation showed no initial benefit for untrained individuals but promoted muscle hypertrophy and strength gains with prolonged, frequent, and high-volume resistance training. It may also improve aerobic and anaerobic power.
population_specificity: Healthy adults aged 18-50, including both trained and untrained individuals.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to explore the physiological and nutritional interactions in concurrent training (endurance and resistance exercise) and identify optimal strategies to support it.
results_summary: The abstract highlights that endurance exercise after resistance training may impair strength gains, but the physiological mechanisms remain unclear. It also notes a lack of knowledge on optimal nutritional strategies for concurrent training and suggests protein supplementation as a key focus.
population_specificity: Athletes seeking to maximize strength and endurance (specific demographics not detailed).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to investigate the effects of 2 months of resistance training and different protein diets on plasma myostatin (MSTN) and other biomarkers related to muscle growth and inflammation.
results_summary: The study found a significant increase in plasma MSTN after resistance training in the high-protein group, which positively correlated with IGF-1 levels. No significant differences were observed between groups for inflammatory markers, muscle mass, or strength, suggesting overlapping effects despite differing protein intakes.
population_specificity: 18 healthy volunteers divided into high-protein and normal-protein groups.
effective_dosage: High-protein group: 1.8 g/kg body weight/day; normal-protein group: 0.85 g/kg body weight/day.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether creatine supplementation combined with resistance training (RT) enhances muscle mass, strength, and functional performance in older adults compared to RT alone.
results_summary: Cr + RT significantly increased total body mass, fat-free mass, chest press and leg press strength, and performance in the 30-second chair stand test compared to RT alone, but had no effect on fat mass, knee extension, biceps curl strength, or isokinetic/isometric torque.
population_specificity: Older adults (average age ~64 years)

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether eccentric (ECC) or concentric (CONC) resistance training, combined with whey protein hydrolysate and carbohydrate (WPH + CHO) supplementation, differentially affects anabolic signaling, muscle protein synthesis (MPS), and muscle hypertrophy.
results_summary: ECC contractions maintained acute anabolic signaling longer than CONC, but MPS did not differ between contraction types. After 12 weeks, both ECC and CONC training increased hypertrophy more with WPH + CHO supplementation than with CHO alone, regardless of contraction mode.
population_specificity: 24 human participants performing unilateral resistance training.
effective_dosage: Not specified (isocaloric WPH + CHO or CHO supplementation).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to examine the efficacy of creatine supplementation, with or without resistance training, in improving muscle strength, lean mass, and bone health in vulnerable older women.
results_summary: The study found that creatine supplementation combined with resistance training (CR+RT) significantly improved muscle strength (1-RM leg press and bench press) and appendicular lean mass compared to other groups, but did not affect bone mass or fat mass. Resistance training alone (PL+RT) also improved muscle strength but not as effectively as CR+RT.
population_specificity: Vulnerable older women (60 subjects).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to compare the effects of creatine supplementation before versus after supervised resistance training on muscle mass, strength, and protein catabolism in healthy older adults.
results_summary: Both groups showed significant increases in lean tissue mass, muscle thickness, and strength, along with reduced muscle protein catabolism, with no differences between creatine timing. Kidney function remained unchanged.
population_specificity: Healthy older adults (n=22, split into two groups of 11).
effective_dosage: 0.1g/kg creatine before or after training, 3 days/week.

study_goal: To examine the effects of 12 weeks of periodized resistance training with and without creatine and whey protein supplementation on body composition, muscular strength, and functional performance in older adults.
results_summary: Resistance training alone and with supplementation improved lean body mass, reduced fat mass, and enhanced strength and functional performance, but supplementation did not provide additional benefits over training alone. Both groups showed significant improvements in bench press, leg press, stair-climbing power, and 400-m walk time compared to controls.
population_specificity: 22 male volunteers aged 68.1 ± 6.1 years.
effective_dosage: RTS group consumed 0.3 g/kg/day creatine for 5 days, then 0.07 g/kg/day, plus one 35 g liquid protein drink daily.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine if circuit resistance training (CRT) improves fitness attributes in individuals with chronic tetraplegia and whether protein supplementation (PS) enhances these adaptations.
results_summary: CRT significantly increased muscular strength (8%-11% per 3-month period), aerobic capacity (35% with immediate PS), and anaerobic fatigue resistance (40W median difference with immediate PS) in individuals with tetraplegia. Timely protein supplementation further enhanced aerobic and anaerobic benefits.
population_specificity: Individuals with chronic tetraplegia
effective_dosage: 36-37g whey protein split before and after exercise (immediate PS) or 24h postexercise (delayed PS)

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the effects of the prohormone 3β-hydroxy-5α-androst-1-en-17-one on body composition, muscular strength, and markers of health in resistance-trained men.
results_summary: The prohormone significantly improved lean body mass, reduced fat mass, and increased strength compared to placebo, but also caused adverse effects including worsened cardiovascular health and liver function markers.
population_specificity: 17 resistance-trained men (23 ± 1 yr; 13.1 ± 1.5% body fat).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether creatine supplementation alone (without resistance training) improves muscular performance, body composition, and bone health in older adults.
results_summary: Creatine supplementation without resistance training appears to enhance muscular strength, power, endurance, lean body mass, and functional capacity in older adults, with potential benefits for bone density. However, effects vary by muscle size, and the underlying mechanisms require further research.
population_specificity: Sedentary elderly individuals

study_goal: The researchers aimed to assess the effects of graded doses of testosterone on serum markers of oxidative stress, chemotaxis, adhesion, and inflammation in healthy younger and older men, not specifically Resistance Training.
results_summary: The study found that increasing doses of testosterone reduced total 8-iso-PGF(2α) in younger men but not older men, with no significant effects on other atherogenic biomarkers. Testosterone did not adversely affect atherogenic biomarkers over a wide dose range.
population_specificity: Healthy eugonadal men (61 aged 18-35 and 60 aged 60-75)
effective_dosage: Weekly injections of 25, 50, 125, 300, or 600 mg testosterone enanthate

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether combining creatine supplementation with resistance training provides greater musculoskeletal benefits compared to resistance training alone in aging populations.
results_summary: The meta-analyses indicated that creatine supplementation combined with resistance training positively affects aging muscle mass and upper body strength more than resistance training alone. Creatine also showed potential benefits for bone mineral density and bone biology.
population_specificity: Aging individuals (specific age range not mentioned)

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the risks and benefits of dietary supplements, particularly protein-containing products, among individuals engaged in resistance training.
results_summary: The study highlights significant risks associated with unregulated dietary supplements, including contamination and adverse health effects, but suggests that protein powders from major manufacturers pose a low risk if quality-tested.
population_specificity: Athletes, recreational exercisers, military personnel, and general consumers.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine if post-exercise consumption of rice protein isolate could enhance recovery and improve body composition compared to whey protein isolate when given in large, isocaloric doses during resistance training.
results_summary: The abstract does not provide specific results, but the study compares the effects of rice protein isolate and whey protein isolate on recovery and body composition changes during resistance training.
population_specificity: Not specified in the abstract.
effective_dosage: Large, isocaloric doses (specific amounts not detailed).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to compare the effects of repeated-sprint training (RST) alone versus combined RST and resistance training with superimposed vibrations on repeated-sprint ability and lower-body power output in male rugby players.
results_summary: Combined RST and resistance training led to greater improvements in repeated-sprint performance and muscle power output compared to RST alone. While both groups showed substantial improvements in RSA mean time and squat absolute power, only the combined training group saw significant gains in RSA best time and normalized squat power output.
population_specificity: Male rugby players (n=20, divided into two groups of 10).
effective_dosage: RST group: 2 days/week; RS+ST group: RST 1 day/week + squat resistance training with superimposed vibrations 1 day/week (volume matched to RST).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to explore the role of resistance training in addressing sarcopenia and osteoporosis, focusing on its benefits for muscle and bone health in aging individuals.
results_summary: The study found that resistance training, combined with adequate nutrition and vitamin D, is crucial for improving muscle strength and bone density, thereby mitigating the effects of sarcopenia and osteoporosis. It highlighted the interconnectedness of muscle and bone health and the importance of lifestyle interventions.
population_specificity: Aging individuals, particularly those at risk of sarcopenia and osteoporosis.
effective_dosage: Resistance training several times per week (specific dosage not detailed).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to investigate the molecular regulation of muscle protein breakdown, synthesis, myogenesis, and transcription in response to resistance training in patients with COPD and healthy controls.
results_summary: Resistance training increased lean mass (~5%) and strength (~20%) in all groups, but molecular responses were blunted in COPD patients except for myogenic signaling. Nutritional supplementation did not enhance functional or molecular responses to training.
population_specificity: 59 patients with COPD (mean age 68.0 years, FEV1 46.9% predicted) and 21 healthy controls (mean age 66.1 years, FEV1 105.0% predicted).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine the effects of testosterone supplementation with and without progressive resistance training (PRT) on functional performance, strength, and body composition in older men with low-normal testosterone levels.
results_summary: PRT improved function and strength similarly in both testosterone- and placebo-treated subjects, while testosterone supplementation alone improved body composition and upper body strength in non-exercisers. Testosterone supplementation was well tolerated with fewer cardiovascular events compared to placebo.
population_specificity: Generally healthy community-dwelling older men (66 ± 5 years) with low-normal baseline total testosterone levels (200-350 ng/dL).
effective_dosage: Transdermal testosterone gel targeting either 400-550 ng/dL (lower dose) or 600-1000 ng/dL (higher dose).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether carbohydrate supplementation before and during resistance training with superimposed electromyostimulation (SEMS) improves glucose availability and total force output.
results_summary: Carbohydrate ingestion increased plasma glucose and total force output during the exercise protocol compared to placebo, but no significant differences were found for nonesterified fatty acids or glycerol.
population_specificity: Six elite resistance-trained male subjects
effective_dosage: 1 g/kg body mass loading dose, followed by 0.17 g/kg every 6 minutes during exercise
study_duration: Until failure occurred during the exercise protocol

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether whey protein supplementation enhances gains in lean body mass, strength, and physical function in elderly individuals undergoing a 12-week resistance exercise program compared to isocaloric carbohydrate supplementation.
results_summary: The study found that resistance training significantly increased lean body mass, strength, and physical function, but whey protein supplementation did not provide additional benefits over carbohydrate supplementation. No significant differences were observed between the two groups in any of the primary outcomes.
population_specificity: Elderly men and women aged 65-91 years.
effective_dosage: 20 g of whey protein or isocaloric carbohydrate immediately after each workout, three times per week.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether whey protein concentrate supplementation enhances resistance training-induced improvements in muscle mass, strength, and physical performance in mobility-limited older adults.
results_summary: Both whey protein and control groups showed increases in lean mass, muscle cross-sectional area, strength, and stair-climbing performance, but there were no significant differences between the groups. The study concluded that whey protein supplementation did not provide additional benefits beyond resistance training alone.
population_specificity: Mobility-limited adults aged 70-85 years.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to investigate the feasibility of 12 weeks of progressive resistance training (PRT) with or without protein and creatine supplementation in HNSCC patients and assess its effects on lean body mass, muscle strength, and functional performance.
results_summary: PRT was feasible with high adherence (97%). Both groups showed significant increases in muscle strength and functional performance, with the PROCR group showing a significant increase in lean body mass (2.6 kg) and the PLA group showing a borderline significant increase (1.3 kg). No significant group differences were found.
population_specificity: Patients with head and neck squamous cell carcinoma (HNSCC) treated with radiotherapy.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the effects of resistance training combined with increased energy intake or protein supplementation on lean body mass, resting metabolic rate, and cardiovascular risk factors.
results_summary: Resistance training for 12 weeks increased resting metabolic rate and lean body mass similarly with either increased energy intake or protein supplementation, but the rise in RMR exceeded expectations based on lean mass gain. Fasting insulin and ApoB levels increased in the fast-food group, but long-term follow-up showed no sustained differences in RMR or body composition.
population_specificity: 24 healthy males aged 19-32 years.
effective_dosage: 33 g whey protein/day or 1350 kcal fast-food meal/day.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether whey protein supplementation enhances resistance training-induced improvements in elbow flexor muscle strength and size.
results_summary: The study found no significant difference in muscle strength or size gains between the protein supplementation and placebo groups after 12 weeks of resistance training, with both groups showing similar improvements.
population_specificity: 33 previously untrained, healthy young men with controlled habitual protein intake.
effective_dosage: Protein or placebo consumed immediately before and after each training session (specific dosage not mentioned).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine the effects of whey protein supplementation combined with resistance training on antioxidant status and cardiovascular risk factors in overweight young men.
results_summary: Resistance training alone or with whey protein improved antioxidant markers (TAC, glutathione, vitamin C) and some cardiovascular risk factors (LDL, triglycerides, HDL), with greater improvements observed in the whey protein group. No significant changes were seen in fibrinogen, blood glucose, blood pressure, WHR, or BMI.
population_specificity: Overweight young men (age 23.4±3.6 years, BMI 25-30 kg/m²).
effective_dosage: Not specified for whey protein; resistance training was 3 sessions/week at 60-70% 1RM.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to investigate the molecular regulation of muscle mass during rehabilitation after immobilization, focusing on the effects of resistance training and protein/carbohydrate supplementation.
results_summary: The study found no changes in protein expression or phosphorylation related to muscle mass regulators after immobilization and rehabilitation. Unexpectedly, significant changes were observed in housekeeping genes, questioning their reliability for normalization in muscle immobilization studies.
population_specificity: Individuals undergoing limb immobilization followed by rehabilitation.
effective_dosage: Not specified (protein/carbohydrate supplementation details not provided).
study_duration: 2 weeks immobilization followed by 6 weeks rehabilitation (Study 2).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine the treatment effect of electromyographic biofeedback (EMGBF) on quadriceps strength compared to placebo and traditional exercise interventions in healthy and pathological populations.
results_summary: EMGBF showed stronger effects compared to placebo and exercise-only interventions, particularly in pathological populations like those with knee osteoarthritis, but definitive evidence of its benefit was inconclusive due to wide confidence intervals in some studies.
population_specificity: Healthy individuals and pathological populations (e.g., knee osteoarthritis patients).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine the effects of vitamin C/E supplementation alone or combined with resistance training on antioxidant/pro-oxidant status, muscle strength, and body composition in elderly individuals.
results_summary: Resistance training combined with vitamin C/E supplementation improved plasma antioxidant profiles but did not affect pro-oxidant status or strength gain. Body composition showed significant changes, though no differences were noted in strength improvements.
population_specificity: Elderly men and women (mean age 65.6 ± 3.8 years).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the association between chronic low-grade inflammatory profile (CLIP) and sarcopenia, and the effects of exercise interventions, including resistance training, on CLIP.
results_summary: Resistance training demonstrated beneficial effects on CLIP, even without reductions in weight, BMI, or fat mass. Exercise-induced IL-6 changes were noted but require careful interpretation due to its dual role in inflammation and exercise response.
population_specificity: Older adults with age-related sarcopenia and chronic low-grade inflammation.

study_goal: To determine changes in body composition, physical performance, metabolic and hormonal parameters induced by resistance training with or without soy protein supplementation in middle-aged males.
results_summary: Resistance training, especially with soy protein supplementation, improved body composition (reduced fat mass, increased lean body mass), physical strength, and metabolic/hormonal parameters, with no significant changes in body weight.
population_specificity: 40 healthy middle-aged men (50-65 years, BMI 25-29.9 kg/m²).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine the impact of vitamin D supplementation on body composition, muscle function, and glucose tolerance in overweight and obese adults undergoing resistance training.
results_summary: Vitamin D supplementation led to early improvements in peak power at 4 weeks and was associated with a reduced waist-to-hip ratio, but no other significant benefits were observed. Resistance training alone did not show additional notable effects beyond these outcomes.
population_specificity: Overweight and obese adults (age: 26.1±4.7 y; BMI: 31.3±3.2 kg/m²; baseline 25-hydroxyvitamin D: 19.3±7.2 ng/mL).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to compare the effects of heavy resistance, explosive resistance, and muscle endurance training on neuromuscular, endurance, and high-intensity running performance in recreational endurance runners.
results_summary: Heavy and explosive resistance training improved maximal strength and neuromuscular characteristics, while heavy resistance training also enhanced high-intensity running performance. All three training modes improved maximal endurance running performance, with minimal effects on VO₂max and running economy.
population_specificity: 27 male recreational endurance runners
study_duration: 8-week resistance training program (following 6 weeks of preparatory training)

study_goal: The researchers aimed to examine the role of sex hormonal status in sarcopenia development and evaluate the effectiveness of interventions like resistance training for its prevention and treatment.
results_summary: Resistance training was found effective in attenuating age-related muscle loss and strength, though hormonal supplementation results were contradictory. Further research is needed to identify other mechanisms and interventions for sarcopenia.
population_specificity: Postmenopausal women

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine the effects of creatine supplementation, both independently and combined with resistance training, on muscle mass, strength, fatigue resistance, and cognitive function in older adults.
results_summary: The study found that creatine supplementation, with or without resistance training, increased lean body mass, muscle strength, fatigue resistance, and performance in activities of daily living in older adults. Additionally, creatine supplementation improved cognitive processing in cases of impairment due to aging or sleep deprivation.
population_specificity: Older adults
effective_dosage: 20 g/day for 5 days or 2 g/day for 30 days

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether acute arginine α-ketoglutarate (AAKG) supplementation improves local muscle endurance of the arm and shoulder girdle or affects blood pressure response during anaerobic exercise.
results_summary: AAKG supplementation did not improve muscle endurance or significantly affect blood pressure response. Subjects performed fewer total chin-ups and trial repetitions with the supplement compared to placebo, suggesting AAKG may hinder muscular endurance.
population_specificity: Twelve trained college-aged men (22.6 ± 3.8 years).
effective_dosage: 3,700 mg arginine alpha-ketoglutarate per serving, administered 4 hours before and 30 minutes before exercise.
study_duration: Acute (single-day intervention with trials separated by at least 1 week).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine if creatine supplementation, taken before and after resistance training with different dosing frequencies (2 or 3 days per week), enhances muscle size and strength gains in young adults.
results_summary: All groups showed increased strength and muscle thickness, but creatine groups (CR2 and CR3) had greater gains in elbow flexor muscle thickness compared to placebo groups. Men on creatine experienced significantly higher leg press strength gains than women on creatine.
population_specificity: 38 physically active, non-resistance-trained university students (21-28 years old, mixed gender).
effective_dosage: CR2: 0.15 g/kg creatine 2 days/week; CR3: 0.10 g/kg creatine 3 days/week.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether resistance training and/or testosterone supplementation alters the transcription and expression of nitric oxide synthase (NOS) isoenzymes in the skeletal muscle of men with severe COPD.
results_summary: Resistance training combined with testosterone supplementation increased eNOS and nNOS proteins and decreased iNOS protein in skeletal muscle. These changes suggest potential benefits of these therapies in improving muscle function in COPD patients.
population_specificity: 40 men with severe COPD (age 67.7 ± 8.3, FEV1 41.4 ± 12.6% predicted).
effective_dosage: Not specified for resistance training; testosterone dosage not detailed in abstract.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to assess the combined effect of resistance training and isoflavones on body composition and cardiovascular risk factors in overweight-to-obese postmenopausal women.
results_summary: Resistance training significantly improved total fat mass, fat mass percentage, and lean body mass, with no synergistic effects observed between exercise and isoflavones, though isoflavones alone showed a beneficial effect on leg fat mass percentage.
population_specificity: Overweight-to-obese (BMI 29.9 ± 3.2 kg/m²) postmenopausal women.
effective_dosage: Three weekly sessions of resistance training and aerobics.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine the effects of an aromatase and 5-α reductase inhibitor on strength, body composition, and hormonal profiles in resistance-trained men.
results_summary: The study found that the supplement significantly reduced percent body fat and increased total and bioavailable testosterone compared to placebo, with no significant changes in anaerobic power, body weight, or safety variables. Significant improvements were also noted in bench- and leg-press 1RM and lean body mass over time.
population_specificity: Resistance-trained men

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether oral creatine supplementation combined with resistance and aerobic training improves physical fitness and health-related quality of life in cardiac patients compared to exercise alone.
results_summary: The study found no additional benefits of creatine supplementation over exercise alone in improving aerobic power, muscle performance, quality of life, or lipid profile in cardiac patients. No adverse effects on renal or liver function were reported.
population_specificity: 70 cardiac patients (4 women, mean age 57.5 years) with coronary artery disease or chronic heart failure.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the combined effect of a meal replacement and a weight loss supplement on body composition, fitness parameters, and clinical health in moderately overweight college-aged individuals undergoing resistance and cardiovascular training.
results_summary: Both groups showed significant improvements in body fat percentage, bench press 1RM, and leg press 1RM. The weight loss supplement group showed improved blood glucose levels and a near-significant reduction in systolic blood pressure, but no additional fitness or body composition benefits compared to placebo.
population_specificity: Moderately overweight college-aged men and women (21-22 years, BMI ~25-30).
effective_dosage: 4 capsules per day and a once-daily meal replacement.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether creatine and protein supplementation provided additional strength gains in middle-aged and older men undergoing resistance training.
results_summary: All groups significantly increased strength and lean body mass after 14 weeks of resistance training, but creatine and/or protein supplementation did not provide additional benefits beyond the training alone.
population_specificity: Middle-aged and older men (aged 48-72 years)
effective_dosage: 5g creatine daily (RTCr, RTCrPr) and/or 35g whey protein daily (RTPr, RTCrPr)

study_goal: The researchers aimed to investigate the diurnal variation in resistance training performance and adaptations, including the effects of timing on muscle hypertrophy and strength gains.
results_summary: The study found that resistance training performance and adaptations peak in the late afternoon, coinciding with optimal physiological conditions, though morning training can blunt diurnal variation. Individual responsiveness to different protocols (strength, power, hypertrophy) varies based on testosterone response.
population_specificity: Not specified (general athletic or resistance-training population implied).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the effectiveness of resistance training in maintaining bone mass in older adults and explore potential additional factors like creatine supplementation.
results_summary: Resistance training helps maintain bone mass by promoting bone-forming cell activity and reducing bone-resorbing cell activity, but bone loss still occurs in older adults despite long-term training, suggesting other factors like nutrition may play a role. Creatine supplementation, with or without resistance training, may influence bone biology, but long-term effects remain understudied.
population_specificity: Older adults experiencing age-related bone and muscle loss.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine the effect of 8-week resistance training combined with creatine supplementation on muscle strength, lean body mass, and serum levels of myostatin and GASP-1.
results_summary: Resistance training significantly decreased serum myostatin and increased GASP-1 levels. Creatine supplementation further reduced myostatin but did not affect GASP-1, amplifying muscle mass gains.
population_specificity: 27 healthy male subjects (23.42±2.2 years)

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether resistant starch from heat-treated jackfruit (JFRS3) could regulate hyperlipidemia through gut microbiota modulation in golden hamsters.
results_summary: JFRS3 showed significant antihyperlipidemic effects, improving blood lipid profiles (increased HDL-C, reduced TG, TC, and LDL-C), alleviating liver fatty lesions, and enhancing gut microbial diversity. It was more effective than raw resistant starch (JFNS) in slowing weight gain and improving metabolic outcomes.
population_specificity: Golden hamsters fed a high-fat diet.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether consuming 42 g of protein pre- and post-exercise improves recovery from acute resistance training sessions in strength/power athletes.
results_summary: The supplement group (SUP) performed significantly more repetitions than the placebo group (PL) at 24 and 48 hours post-exercise, indicating better recovery. No differences were observed in hormonal measures, but creatine kinase (CK) levels remained elevated longer in the PL group.
population_specificity: 15 male strength/power athletes
effective_dosage: 42 g of protein pre- and post-exercise
study_duration: Acute intervention (single session with follow-ups at 24 and 48 hours)

study_goal: The researchers aimed to elucidate how type 3 lotus seed resistant starch (LRS3) and sodium lactate (SL) modulate colonic microbiota and metabolism to mitigate hyperlipidemia in rats.
results_summary: LRS3 increased microbial diversity, shifted microbiota composition toward healthy profiles, and promoted SCFA-producing bacteria while reducing lactic acid-producing bacteria. The co-intervention of LRS3 and SL significantly influenced lipid metabolism-related metabolites and reduced blood lipid levels in hyperlipidemic rats.
population_specificity: High-fat diet-induced hyperlipidemic rats

study_goal: The researchers aimed to systematically discuss the mechanism of Resistant Starch (RS) in diabetes intervention and treatment, and propose a new classification of RS based on preparation methods and formation reasons.
results_summary: The study found that RS plays an important role in diabetes due to its low glycemic index, and proposed a new classification of RS into 10 types to better understand its variations. The mechanisms were discussed at molecular and granular levels, including starch conformation, double-helix structure, and amylase penetration.
population_specificity: Not specified (general discussion, no specific population studied).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine the effects of buckwheat resistant starch (BRS) on lipid metabolism and gut microbiota in hyperlipidemic mice.
results_summary: BRS supplementation significantly reduced body weight, improved lipid profiles (lowered TC, TG, LDL-C, and increased HDL-C), mitigated hepatic steatosis, reduced inflammation (lowered TNF-α and IL-6, increased IL-10), modulated lipid metabolism genes, and enhanced gut microbiota composition and SCFA production.
population_specificity: Hyperlipidemic mice fed a high-fat diet.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine if protein supplementation before heavy resistance training affects postexercise resting energy expenditure and the nonprotein respiratory exchange ratio compared to carbohydrate supplementation.
results_summary: Protein supplementation before resistance training significantly increased resting energy expenditure at 24 hours post-exercise compared to carbohydrate supplementation, though both supplements elevated REE. The respiratory exchange ratio decreased significantly at 24 hours post-exercise for both groups, with no differences in total energy intake or training volume.
population_specificity: Eight resistance-trained subjects (five men and three women).
effective_dosage: 376 kJ of either PRO (18 g whey protein, 2 g carbohydrate, 1.5 g fat) or CHO (1 g whey protein, 19 g carbohydrate, 1 g fat) consumed 20 minutes before training.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether creatine supplementation combined with resistance training improves physical function, lean mass, and quality of life in postmenopausal women with knee osteoarthritis.
results_summary: The study found that creatine supplementation significantly improved physical function, lower limb lean mass, and quality of life compared to placebo, while both groups showed reduced pain and increased leg-press strength.
population_specificity: Postmenopausal women with knee osteoarthritis
effective_dosage: 20 g/day for 1 week, then 5 g/day thereafter

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the efficiency of resistant starch production using malic, citric, and lactic acids after freezing-thawing pre-treatments and compare their effects on starch properties.
results_summary: Freezing-thawing pre-treatments increased the degree of substitution for esterified starch, with lactic acid producing the least swelling capacity and lowest paste viscosities. Resistant starch from FTF pre-treatment showed slowly digestible properties due to cross-linkage formation, reducing heat energy and time consumption.
population_specificity: Not specified (in vitro study)

study_goal: The researchers aimed to elucidate the bioactive mechanism of chickpea-derived resistant starch (RS) in alleviating atopic dermatitis (AD) by examining its effects on gut microbiota and immune balance.
results_summary: Chickpea RS improved AD symptoms and restored Th1/Th2 immune balance in mice, mediated by gut microbiota. It increased beneficial bacteria (Butyricimonas virosa, Bifidobacterium pseudolongum, Faecalibaculum rodentium) and SCFA production, particularly butyrate, which activated GPR109A to inhibit inflammatory pathways.
population_specificity: Mice with AD induced by calcipotriol.
interactions: Antibiotic cocktail treatment eliminated the benefits of chickpea RS, indicating gut microbiota dependence.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether type 5 resistant starch (RS5) derived from Canna edulis could regulate lipid metabolism and improve hyperlipidemia in mice, similar to the known effects of RS3.
results_summary: Ce-RS5 significantly reduced body weight, improved blood lipid levels, alleviated liver damage and fat accumulation, and modulated gut microbiota by increasing beneficial bacteria (e.g., norank_f_Muribaculaceae) while reducing harmful bacteria (e.g., Colidextribacter).
population_specificity: Hyperlipidemia-induced mice

study_goal: The researchers aimed to investigate the thermal stability, digestibility, and physicochemical properties of corn starch sugar residue resistant starch (CSSR-RS) compared to high-amylose corn starch (HS) and normal corn starch (NS).
results_summary: CSSR-RS showed higher resistant starch content (51.76%) and retained 42.6% after high-temperature treatment, demonstrating strong resistance to gelatinization and digestion compared to HS and NS. Its highly ordered molecular structure and C-type crystalline configuration contributed to superior thermal stability and lower in vitro hydrolysis rates.
population_specificity: Not specified (in vitro study).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine the effects of konjac glucomannan (KGM)-embedded corn starch-derived Type 1 resistant starch (RS1) on resistant starch content, rheological properties, gut microbiota, and postprandial blood glucose levels.
results_summary: The study found that KGM-embedded RS1 increased resistant starch content, improved rheological properties, enhanced beneficial gut bacteria, and significantly reduced peak blood glucose levels compared to untreated corn starch.
population_specificity: Individuals with type 2 diabetes and obesity (implied by the focus on postprandial blood glucose improvement).
effective_dosage: 0.1%, 0.3%, 0.5%, and 0.7% KGM embedded in corn starch.
study_duration: Heat-moisture treatment (HMT) was applied for 6 hours; in vivo digestibility experiment duration not specified.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the effects of rice with different resistant starch contents (11-20% vs. 0.1-0.5%) on chronic constipation in older adults.
results_summary: The study protocol describes a randomized controlled trial design but does not report results, as it appears to be a study protocol rather than a completed study. The primary outcome is constipation symptoms, with secondary outcomes including quality of life, depression, anxiety, and sleep quality.
population_specificity: Older adults with chronic constipation residing in long-term care facilities.
effective_dosage: Rice with resistant starch content of 11-20% (Group A) or 0.1-0.5% (Group B), with individualized serving sizes calculated by nutrition experts.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether resistant starch (RS), combined with Ce ions and sulfasalazine in Ce-SASP-RS ICPs, could synergistically treat inflammatory bowel disease (IBD) by modulating redox balance, inflammation, and gut microbiota.
results_summary: The study found that resistant starch, as part of Ce-SASP-RS ICPs, improved gut microbiota modulation by generating short-chain fatty acids, enhanced by the restored metabolic balance of ROS and inflammatory cytokines. The combined approach effectively restored intestinal metabolic microenvironment through multiple mechanisms.
population_specificity: Not specified (implied to be relevant to individuals with inflammatory bowel disease).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the effects of resistant starch (RS) on inflammation, uremic toxins, and renal function in patients with chronic kidney disease (CKD) through a systematic review and meta-analysis.
results_summary: RS dietary intervention significantly reduced indoxyl sulfate (IS) and blood urea nitrogen (BUN) levels but did not affect inflammatory markers like IL-6 or TNF-α. The study concluded that RS may improve renal function and reduce uremic toxins in CKD patients, though results should be interpreted cautiously due to limited sample size and varying dosages.
population_specificity: Patients with chronic kidney disease (CKD)

study_goal: The researchers aimed to assess the effects of Potato resistant starch 3 (PRS3) on glucose tolerance, insulin resistance, lipid metabolism, oxidative stress, inflammation, and gut microbiota in a type 2 diabetes mellitus (T2DM) mouse model.
results_summary: PRS3 significantly improved glucose tolerance and insulin resistance, alleviated abnormal lipid metabolism and oxidative stress, reduced inflammation in the liver and pancreas, and altered gut microbiota composition by increasing beneficial bacteria and decreasing harmful ones.
population_specificity: Type 2 diabetes mellitus (T2DM) mouse model

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether Canna edulis RS3-resistant starch could improve behavioral performance and reduce neuron apoptosis in a rat model of Parkinson's disease.
results_summary: Canna edulis RS3-resistant starch improved behavioral outcomes, reduced inflammatory markers (IL-1β, IL-6, TNF-α), increased TH-positive neurons, and mitigated apoptosis in dopaminergic neurons.
population_specificity: Rotenone-induced Parkinson's disease model rats.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to develop a method to enhance the heat-resistant resistant starch (RS) content by embedding retrograded short-chain amylose (RSCA) into calcium alginate (CA) and evaluate its structural, physicochemical, and digestibility properties.
results_summary: Increasing sodium alginate (SA) concentration resulted in denser CA shells, higher thermal stability (gelatinization temperature >100°C), and increased RS content (72.66% at 2% SA). The beads exhibited low glycemic index (54.72), making them suitable for functional foods targeting obesity and diabetes.
population_specificity: Not specified (in vitro study)

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine how heat-moisture treatments (annealing and pressure heating) affect the structural properties and digestibility of pea-derived Type III resistant starch (RS3) to enhance its RS content.
results_summary: The study found that heat-moisture treatments significantly increased relative crystallinity, particle size, gelatinization temperature, and RS content while reducing swelling power, pasting viscosity, and rapidly digestible starch content. The highest RS content achieved was 85.6% after pressure heating at 20% moisture content, a substantial improvement over the untreated sample (45.6%).
population_specificity: Not specified (in vitro study on pea starch)
effective_dosage: Not specified (processing conditions: 90°C/40-70% moisture for annealing; 121°C/10-40% moisture for pressure heating)

study_goal: The researchers aimed to review recent developments in physical starch modification techniques and their impact on resistant starch's functional and health benefits.
results_summary: The study found that physical modification techniques (e.g., annealing, extrusion, high-pressure processing) effectively increase resistant starch content and improve its functional properties, offering health benefits like better blood sugar regulation and weight control. These methods are economically and ecologically sustainable.
population_specificity: Not specified (review article, no specific population studied).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine how combined nitrogen and sulfur fertilization affects the structural and physicochemical properties of buckwheat resistant starch.
results_summary: Combined fertilization increased resistant starch content, apparent amylose content, particle size, pasting temperature, and gelatinization enthalpy while reducing light transmittance, water solubility, swelling power, and viscosity. The study found significant correlations between resistant starch properties and fertilization effects.
population_specificity: Buckwheat resistant starch (not human or animal subjects).
effective_dosage: Not specified (fertilization levels varied but exact amounts not detailed).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to investigate the effects and mechanisms of Resistant Starch (RS) on diabetic cardiomyopathy (DCM) in mouse models.
results_summary: RS improved myocardial fibrosis, hypertrophy, apoptosis, and cardiac insufficiency in DCM, potentially through elevated IGF-1 expression and ERK phosphorylation. It also altered intestinal microbiota and improved intestinal mucosal permeability.
population_specificity: Mouse models induced by a high-fat diet (HFD) and streptozotocin (STZ).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine the effect of autoclave-enzymatic treatment on fern root starch to enhance resistant starch content and improve its functional properties for industrial applications.
results_summary: Mixed enzyme treatment combined with autoclaving significantly increased resistant starch content (24.07%) compared to native starch, improved water-holding capacity, transparency, and freeze-thaw stability, while reducing solubility, swelling, and viscosity. The modified starch exhibited a denser structure, higher crystallinity, and enhanced thermal stability without forming new functional groups.
population_specificity: Not specified (in vitro study on fern root starch)

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether resistant-starch-encapsulated probiotics (RS-Pro) could mitigate gut microbiota dysbiosis and intestinal mucositis induced by 5-fluorouracil (5-FU) chemotherapy.
results_summary: RS-Pro treatment restored gut microbial diversity, increased beneficial bacteria populations (e.g., Muribaculaceae), and attenuated 5-FU-induced intestinal damage, including villus shortening and leukopenia.
population_specificity: Female BALB/c mice undergoing 5-FU chemotherapy.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to optimize heat-moisture treatment (HMT) conditions for high-amylose starch (HAS) to enhance resistant starch (RS) content and apply it to triticale noodles for developing low-glycemic-index products.
results_summary: HMT significantly increased RS content (60.23% under optimal conditions) and decreased rapidly digestible starch (RDS) in HAS. Incorporating HMT-HAS into triticale noodles raised RS content from 12.08% to 34.41%, improving starch digestive resistance.
population_specificity: Not specified (in vitro or food product study, no human participants mentioned).
effective_dosage: Optimal HMT conditions: 108 °C, 5.8 h, 25.50% moisture content; HMT-HAS incorporation levels in noodles not quantified.
study_duration: Not specified (study focused on treatment optimization, not longitudinal intervention).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether resistant starch intervention could attenuate metabolic syndrome in the ob/ob mouse model and whether the effect was dose-dependent.
results_summary: The study found that resistant starch intervention attenuated metabolic syndrome in the ob/ob mouse model, with the effect being dose-dependent. Higher doses showed more significant improvements in metabolic parameters.
population_specificity: ob/ob mouse model (a model for obesity and metabolic syndrome)

study_goal: The researchers aimed to compare the postprandial glycemic responses between fresh-cooked and refrigerated glutinous and non-glutinous grains after the first and second meals.
results_summary: Cold-stored non-glutinous rice and millet showed significantly lower glycemic responses (24.4% and 29.5% reduction, respectively) compared to fresh-cooked non-glutinous rice. Fresh-cooked non-glutinous millet demonstrated a 39.1% lower glycemic response after the second meal.
population_specificity: Eighteen healthy female participants
effective_dosage: 50 g of carbohydrate per test meal
study_duration: Single meal intervention with follow-up measurements up to 240 min (first meal) and 180 min (second meal)

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether resistant starch (RS) could mitigate 5-FU chemotherapy-induced microbial dysbiosis, inflammation, and cachectic symptoms in colorectal cancer-bearing mice.
results_summary: RS-encapsulated probiotics (RS-Pro) combined with 5-FU chemotherapy suppressed tumor growth, activated apoptosis, reduced inflammatory cytokines, and maintained a healthier gut microbiota composition compared to chemotherapy alone. RS-Pro supplementation also mitigated 5-FU-induced microbial dysbiosis.
population_specificity: Female BALB/cByJNarl mice with CT26 colonic carcinoma.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to identify predictors of gut microbiota response to resistant starch (RS) supplementation to develop precision nutrition approaches for optimizing dietary fiber benefits.
results_summary: Dietary fiber intake and gut microbiome composition predicted changes in specific bacterial variants and fecal short-chain fatty acids (SCFAs) during RS supplementation, though SCFA concentrations increased most during digestible starch supplementation. AMY1-related metrics were not predictive of RS response.
population_specificity: 76 healthy adults (59 completed the study)
effective_dosage: 10-day supplementation periods for RS type 2 (RS2), RS type 4 (RS4), and digestible starch
study_duration: 7-week crossover study with 5-day washout periods between treatments

study_goal: The researchers aimed to investigate how pulsed electric field (PEF)-assisted OSA esterification affects the structure and digestive properties of cassava starch, particularly its resistant starch (RS) content.
results_summary: The study found that PEF-assisted esterification at 3 kV/cm significantly increased RS content by 17.13% compared to native starch, while conventional methods only increased it by 5.91%. Structural changes, such as increased double-helical density, contributed to slower digestion and higher RS content.
population_specificity: Not specified (in vitro or lab-based study on cassava starch).
effective_dosage: Electric field strengths of 1.5-4.5 kV/cm were used for PEF-assisted esterification.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to assess the effects of Type 3 resistant starch from Canna edulis (Ce-RS3) on blood lipids and gut microbiota in patients with mild hyperlipidemia.
results_summary: Ce-RS3 significantly reduced total cholesterol, LDL cholesterol, and non-HDL cholesterol while increasing glutathione peroxidase. It also altered gut microbiota by increasing beneficial genera (Faecalibacterium, Agathobacter) and reducing others (norank_f_Ruminococcaceae, Christensenellaceae_R-7_group), which may regulate lipid metabolism.
population_specificity: 115 patients with mild hyperlipidemia.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate whether terahertz (THz) spectroscopy could accurately quantify resistant starch (RS) content in rice after hydrothermal treatments, as an alternative to traditional in vitro hydrolysis methods.
results_summary: The study confirmed that THz spectroscopy, specifically the second derivative intensities of peaks at 9.0, 10.5, 12.1, and 13.1 THz, correlated strongly with RS content (R² > 0.96) and provided high accuracy in predicting RS levels in hydrothermally treated rice samples.
population_specificity: Rice samples subjected to hydrothermal treatments (soaking, mild heat-moisture treatment, and parboiling).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine the intervention effect of chlorogenic acid coupled with extruded rice starch (CGA-ES) in mitigating lipid metabolism disorders induced by a high-fat diet in rats.
results_summary: CGA-ES significantly improved lipid metabolism by reducing blood glucose, serum cholesterol, triglycerides, and liver enzyme levels, and it enhanced gut microecology by promoting beneficial bacteria and metabolites like butyrate. The resistant starch fraction of CGA-ES was identified as the primary contributor to these effects.
population_specificity: Rats fed a high-fat diet.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to investigate how wheat-resistant starch (WS) complexes with chlorogenic acid (CA) and linoleic acid (LA) alter gut microbiota, metabolites, and repair gut barrier dysfunction induced by a high-fat diet.
results_summary: WS-CA/LA complexes increased resistant starch content, repaired gut barrier function (ZO-1 and MUC-2 levels), promoted beneficial gut microbes (e.g., Parabacteroides, Bacteroides), elevated short-chain fatty acids (SCFAs), and modulated secondary bile acid metabolism by reducing harmful bile acids.
population_specificity: Not specified (likely animal model based on gut barrier dysfunction induced by high-fat diet).
effective_dosage: Not specified (only RS content percentages provided: WS-CA 23.40%, WS-LA 21.25%, WS-CA-LA 35.47%).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to assess the impact of baking processes on the resistant starch (RS) content of five RS-rich ingredients and compare two enzymatic methods for RS determination.
results_summary: Heating and water addition significantly reduced RS content in all ingredients. Hi Maize retained the highest RS levels (84% in model systems, 72% in cakes) and was the only ingredient to meet EU health claim criteria for glycemic response reduction. Differences between RS measurement methods were less significant in cakes than in model systems.
population_specificity: Not specified (likely in vitro or food model systems).
effective_dosage: 50% replacement of wheat flour in reformulated cakes.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine the optimal preparation method for rice-resistant starch and evaluate its effects on glycemic modulation, liver damage, and intestinal flora in diabetic mice.
results_summary: The study found that homogenized coenzyme rice-resistant starch had a better glycemic modulating effect, improved intestinal flora, and enhanced probiotic abundance in diabetic mice compared to normal debranched starch. It also showed potential benefits in reducing liver damage indicators.
population_specificity: db/db type 2 diabetic mice

study_goal: The researchers aimed to investigate the formation mechanism of type 3 resistant starch (RS3) after calcium ion (Ca2+) treatment and evaluate its effects on blood glucose management.
results_summary: Ca2+ treatment increased RS3 content from 9.70% to 22.26%, altered starch structure (reduced crystallinity and double helix degree), and enhanced carbohydrate metabolism regulation, suggesting improved blood glucose management potential.
population_specificity: Not specified (in vitro study on starch properties).
effective_dosage: Not specified (Ca2+ treatment concentration not detailed).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether combining resistant starch (RS) with other fibers (xylan or cellulose) could enhance its prebiotic effects in the distal gut compared to RS alone.
results_summary: RS alone had limited impact on distal gut microbiota due to rapid fermentation, but combining RS with xylan or cellulose prolonged fermentation, increased beneficial bacteria (e.g., Blautia), and boosted SCFA production. RS with cellulose also enriched fecal bacterial diversity.
population_specificity: Ileum-cannulated growing pigs (n=24).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to improve the thermal stability of resistant starch (RS5) and evaluate its glycemic index (GI) potential for low-GI food development.
results_summary: The starch-linoleic acid complex (RS5) showed high resistant starch content (46.7%) and lower predicted glycemic index values (54.5–64.2). Recombinant rice made from the complex retained significant resistant starch (38.1%) and maintained textural properties similar to commercial rice.
population_specificity: Not specified (in vitro or food product study)

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine how dual hydrothermal treatment affects the resistant starch (RS) content, structure, and properties of modified rice flour compared to single hydrothermal treatment and untreated rice flour.
results_summary: Dual hydrothermal treatment increased RS content, crystallinity, and short-range ordering in modified rice flour, while reducing viscoelasticity and improving thermal stability compared to single treatment or untreated flour. The modified flour's gel structure primarily consisted of free water with minimal bound or immobile water.
population_specificity: Not specified (in vitro study on rice flour)

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the potential of Resistant Starch (RS) to improve glycemic control and its mechanisms of action in glucose metabolism, particularly for individuals with type 2 diabetes.
results_summary: RS shows promise in improving glucose metabolism and insulin sensitivity, likely through fermentation into short-chain fatty acids and bile acid modulation. However, its efficacy as a medical nutrition therapy for type 2 diabetes requires further investigation via large-scale interventions.
population_specificity: Individuals with diabetes mellitus (specific type not further detailed in the abstract).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to investigate the hypoglycemic effects of two types of recrystallized resistant starches (A-type and B-type) in type 2 diabetic mice.
results_summary: Medium-dose ARS significantly reduced fasting blood glucose, triglycerides, and LDL while increasing HDL. High-dose ARS, BRS, and ABRS increased peptide YY and GLP-1 levels, and medium-dose ARS and BRS increased butyric acid yield. ARS also improved gut microbiota composition.
population_specificity: Type 2 diabetic mice
effective_dosage: Low-, medium-, and high-dose ARS; high-dose BRS; high-dose ARS combined with BRS (ABRS)

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine how different preparation methods (hydrothermal, ultrasonication, alkali) affect the multiscale structure and digestibility of type III resistant starch (RS3) derived from high amylose maize starch (HAMS).
results_summary: Hydrothermal-alkali combined with ultrasonication (RS-HAU) most effectively disrupted HAMS structure, increased crystallinity and thermal stability, and yielded the highest resistant starch content (69.40%). Other methods had weaker structural effects.
population_specificity: Not specified (in vitro study on starch samples).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to improve the prebiotic properties and resistant starch content of modified corn flour (MCF) Momala Gorontalo using physical, chemical, and enzymatic modification processes.
results_summary: The study found that various modification methods significantly increased resistant starch content, with acid hydrolysis (HA) and debranching pullulanase (DP) showing the highest increases (5.0-fold and 3.8-fold, respectively). HA and DP modifications also demonstrated notable prebiotic activity and resistance to simulated gastric fluid hydrolysis compared to unmodified corn flour.
population_specificity: Not specified (in vitro or model system implied).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the effect of hot-extrusion treatment with starch-proanthocyanidins interactions on the nutritional properties of chestnut starch, particularly its resistant starch content and functional benefits.
results_summary: HEX-PR treatment increased resistant starch content from 3.25% to 12.35%, enhanced α-amylase inhibitory, antioxidant, and antiglycation activities, and improved short-chain fatty acid production and beneficial gut bacteria like Bifidobacterium.
population_specificity: Not specified (likely in vitro or animal model based on abstract).
effective_dosage: Not specified (PR concentration varied but exact amounts not provided).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to investigate the potential benefits and underlying mechanisms of resistant starch for treating metabolic dysfunction-associated steatotic liver disease.
results_summary: The abstract previews a randomized controlled clinical trial but does not provide specific results regarding resistant starch's effects.
population_specificity: Global adult population with metabolic dysfunction-associated steatotic liver disease.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the potential of starch-ascorbyl palmitate inclusion complexes (RS5) as a new type of resistant starch by assessing their in vitro digestion kinetics and in vivo glycemic response in mice.
results_summary: The study found that ANN-ACH treated V6h-AP IC exhibited the lowest hydrolysis rate, equilibrium concentration, and glycemic index (eGI of 54.83 in vitro, 39.53 in vivo), indicating a more favorable effect on postprandial blood glucose modulation compared to other samples and RS2.
population_specificity: C57BL/6J mice

study_goal: The researchers aimed to investigate the effects of high-amylose maize starch (HAMS) and starch-entrapped microspheres (MS) on metabolic disorder and gut microbiome dysbiosis in mice fed a high-fat diet.
results_summary: MS more effectively controlled body weight, adipose tissue mass, and reduced blood glucose, insulin, lipid, and pro-inflammatory cytokine levels compared to HAMS. MS also altered gut microbiota composition, promoting beneficial metabolic pathways and increasing fecal short-chain fatty acids, particularly propionate.
population_specificity: High-fat diet-induced obese mice.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to investigate the relationship between the multi-scale structure of black Tartary buckwheat resistant starch (RS) and its digestibility after autoclaving and autoclave-debranching treatments.
results_summary: Autoclaving and autoclave-debranching treatments altered the starch structure, increasing thermal stability, forming flavonoid-starch complexes, and enhancing resistance to digestion. The autoclave-debranching co-treatment notably improved digestibility resistance, crystallinity, and amylose content.
population_specificity: Black Tartary buckwheat starch (no human or animal subjects mentioned).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to investigate whether resistant starch (RS) could serve as an effective microbiota-directed dietary supplement for treating non-alcoholic fatty liver disease (NAFLD).
results_summary: The RS intervention resulted in a 9.08% absolute reduction in intrahepatic triglyceride content (IHTC), with a 5.89% reduction after adjusting for weight loss.
